text: The burden of Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum the Elkoshite.
The Lord is a jealous and avenging God,The Lord avengeth and is full of wrath;The Lord taketh vengeance on His adversaries,And He reserveth wrath for His enemies.
The Lord is long-suffering, and great in power,And will by no means clear the guilty;The Lord, in the whirlwind and in the storm is His way,And the clouds are the dust of His feet.
He rebuketh the sea, and maketh it dry,<po2>And drieth up all the rivers;<po3>Bashan languisheth, and Carmel,<po4>And the flower of Lebanon languisheth.
The mountains quake at Him,<po2>And the hills melt;<po3>And the earth is upheaved at His presence,<po4>Yea, the world, and all that dwell therein.
Who can stand before His indignation?<po2>And who can abide in the fierceness of His anger?<po3>His fury is poured out like fire,<po4>And the rocks are broken asunder before Him.
The Lord is good,A stronghold in the day of trouble;And He knoweth them that take refuge in Him.
But with an overrunning flood<po2>He will make a full end of the place thereof,<po3>And darkness shall pursue His enemies.
What do ye devise against the Lord?He will make a full end;Trouble shall not rise up the second time.
For though they be like tangled thorns,<po2>And be drunken according to their drink,<po3>They shall be devoured as stubble fully dry.
Out of thee came he forth,That deviseth evil against the Lord,That counselleth wickedness.
Thus saith the Lord:Though they be in full strength, and likewise many,Even so shall they be cut down, and he shall pass away;And though I have afflicted thee, I will afflict thee no more.
And now will I break his yoke from off thee,<po2>And will burst thy bonds in sunder.

And the Lord hath given commandment concerning thee,That no more of thy name be sown;Out of the house of thy god will I cut offThe graven image and the molten image;I will make thy grave; for thou art become worthless.

Behold upon the mountains the feet of him<po2>That bringeth good tidings, that announceth peace!<po3>Keep thy feasts, O Judah,<po4>Perform thy vows;<po5>For the wicked one shall no more pass through thee;<po6>He is utterly cut off.
A maul is come up before thy face;<po2>Guard the defences,<po3>Watch the way, make thy loins strong,<po4>Fortify thy power mightily!—
For the Lord restoreth the pride of Jacob,As the pride of Israel;For the emptiers have emptied them out,And marred their vine-branches.—
The shield of his mighty men is made red,<po2>The valiant men are in scarlet;<po3>The chariots are fire of steel in the day of his preparation,<po4>And the cypress spears are made to quiver.
The chariots rush madly in the streets,<po2>They jostle one against another in the broad places;<po3>The appearance of them is like torches,<po4>They run to and fro like the lightnings.
He bethinketh himself of his worthies;<po2>They stumble in their march;<po3>They make haste to the wall thereof,<po4>And the mantelet is prepared.
The gates of the rivers are opened,<po2>And the palace is dissolved.
And the queen is uncovered, she is carried away,<po2>And her handmaids moan as with the voice of doves,<po3>Tabering upon their breasts.
But Nineveh hath been from of old like a pool of water;<po2>Yet they flee away;<po3>‘Stand, stand’;<po4>But none looketh back.
Take ye the spoil of silver, take the spoil of gold;<po2>For there is no end of the store,<po3>Rich with all precious vessels.
She is empty, and void, and waste;<po2>And the heart melteth, and the knees smite together,<po3>And convulsion is in all loins,<po4>And the faces of them all have gathered blackness.
Where is the den of the lions,<po2>Which was the feeding-place of the young lions,<po3>Where the lion and the lioness walked, and the lion’s whelp,<po4>And none made them afraid?
The lion did tear in pieces enough for his whelps,<po2>And strangled for his lionesses,<po3>And filled his caves with prey,<po4>And his dens with ravin.

Behold, I am against thee, saith the Lord of hosts,And I will burn her chariots in the smoke,And the sword shall devour thy young lions;And I will cut off thy prey from the earth,And the voice of thy messengers shall no more be heard.
Woe to the bloody city!<po2>It is all full of lies and rapine;<po3>The prey departeth not.
Hark! the whip, and hark! the rattling of the wheels;<po2>And prancing horses, and bounding chariots;

The horseman charging,<po2>And the flashing sword, and the glittering spear;<po3>And a multitude of slain, and a heap of carcases;<po4>And there is no end of the corpses, and they stumble upon their corpses;
Because of the multitude of the harlotries of the well-favoured harlot,<po2>The mistress of witchcrafts,<po3>That selleth nations through her harlotries,<po4>And families through her witchcrafts.
Behold, I am against thee, saith the Lord of hosts,And I will uncover thy skirts upon thy face,And I will shew the nations thy nakedness,And the kingdoms thy shame.
And I will cast detestable things upon thee, and make thee vile,<po2>And will make thee as dung.
And it shall come to pass, that all they that look upon thee<po2>Shall flee from thee,<po3>And say: ‘Nineveh is laid waste;<po4>Who will bemoan her? Whence shall I seek comforters for thee?’
Art thou better than No-amon,<po2>That was situate among the rivers,<po3>That had the waters round about her;<po4>Whose rampart was the sea, and of the sea her wall?
Ethiopia and Egypt were thy strength, and it was infinite;<po2>Put and Lubim were thy helpers.

Yet was she carried away,<po2>She went into captivity;<po3>Her young children also were dashed in pieces<po4>At the head of all the streets;<po5>And they cast lots for her honourable men,<po6>And all her great men were bound in chains.
Thou also shalt be drunken,<po2>Thou shalt swoon;<po3>Thou also shalt seek a refuge<po4>Because of the enemy.
All thy fortresses shall be like fig-trees with the first-ripe figs:<po2>If they be shaken, they fall into the mouth of the eater.
Behold, thy people in the midst of thee are women;<po2>The gates of thy land are set wide open unto thine enemies;<po3>The fire hath devoured thy bars.
Draw thee water for the siege,<po2>Strengthen thy fortresses;<po3>Go into the clay, and tread the mortar,<po4>Lay hold of the brickmould.
There shall the fire devour thee;<po2>The sword shall cut thee off,<po3>It shall devour thee like the canker-worm;<po4>Make thyself many as the canker-worm,<po5>Make thyself many as the locusts.
Thou hast multiplied thy merchants<po2>Above the stars of heaven;<po3>The canker-worm spreadeth itself, and flieth away.

Thy crowned are as the locusts,<po2>And thy marshals as the swarms of grasshoppers,<po3>Which camp in the walls in the cold day,<po4>But when the sun ariseth they flee away,<po5>And their place is not known where they are.
Thy shepherds slumber, O king of Assyria,<po2>Thy worthies are at rest;<po3>Thy people are scattered upon the mountains,<po4>And there is none to gather them.
There is no assuaging of thy hurt,<po2>Thy wound is grievous;<po3>All that hear the report of thee<po4>Clap the hands over thee;<po5>For upon whom hath not thy wickedness passed continually?
